description.text: During my senior year of college I lived at 47 Mason Street in Somerville. For fun I made a 3D model combining 47 with Mason and later made it into singlets for my housemates.

The stl was just printed out using ReplicatorG - the silver one was printed in PLA on an Ultimaker and the white one in ABS on a Replicator.
The DXF's were cut in acrylic using a laser cutter. To make the singlets I pinned each one to cardboard then used fabric spray paint.

I suggest you attach 14awg solid wires about 6" long before closing it.

I wanted to be able to replace my existing switches in my house with sonoff, I got inspiration from 530_projects design, but decided to design my own version. I like the feel of it when depressing the button

title: Camera Bed Mount for Wanhao i3 / Maker Select V2 (with RepRapChampion aluminum carriage plate upgrade)

description.text:
This is a mounting bracket that can be used to attach webcams or other small cameras to the front of the carriage plate (below the heated bed) on a Wanhao i3 or Monoprice Maker Select v2, so that the camera moves with the bed - great for time-lapses.

IMPORTANT! -- THIS MOUNT WILL ONLY ATTACH TO PRINTERS THAT HAVE THE REPRAP CHAMPION ALUMINUM CARRIAGE PLATE UPGRADE (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MUAMRN7/) - IT WILL NOT ATTACH TO THE ORIGINAL PLATE THAT COMES WITH THE PRINTER!

I wanted to design a mounting bracket that did not interfere with access to the bed leveling thumbwheels - there are camera mounts out there that attach to the bed mounting screws which means they partially block access to the thumbwheels. This bracket is very low-profile when no camera is mounted, so it really is very unobtrusive. Mounts can be made for different types of cameras - I'm including two here in case they are useful -- basically they just need to have a 14.5mm diameter circular base that will slide into the hole on the bracket. Camera mounts can be installed or removed very easily without taking the main mounting bracket off the printer.

Notes on included camera mounts (edited/updated 2/20/18)

I've made three camera mounts to attach to the bracket, all of which are included here.

  • The first is a base for luc_e's Logitech c270 tripod (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1228521) - the tripod arms slot directly into the base.
  • The second is a mount for my Thieye T5e action camera - this is very similar to a GoPro, but the dimensions are not identical.
  • I've also made a GoPro-compatible version - this is based on the dimensions used for other GoPro mounts posted on Thingiverse, so it should work - however I don't have a GoPro myself so I can't test it. If you print it out and it doesn't work with a GoPro, please let me know! :)

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

The main mount is attached very close to the heated bed, so it should be printed with a material that can handle some heat, such as ABS or PETG. The individual camera mounts can be printed using any material you want.

You need to attach the pressure bar to the mounting bracket using two 45mm M3 bolts with 4 nuts. You also need two compression springs mounted on the two screws; these push the pressure bar against the aluminum plate to lock the mount in place. (See the photo taken from below the printer, that shows how the bracket connects to the carriage plate - this shows also how the bolts and springs are attached.)

The individual camera mounts fit tightly enough into the 15mm hole in the mount so that they don't really need any additional screws to hold them in place; however there is a hole for an M2 screw in the front of the mount in case you do want to really lock the individual camera mount in position.

This is a quick modification to Slug's Caliburn MuzzleVF1 file, which is an extended muzzle break essentially. It is a friction fit onto the aluminum barrel and doesn't require screws to be attached. I found that the muzzle would be off-axis from the barrel because of the single screw point and I wanted it to work for when I eventually swap out for a longer barrel.

comments.text: You may want to look at the updated Muzzle4 piece I added to the Caliburn page. You could re-purpose the slot and side hole features from it for this so that a pair of 4-40 hex nuts and screws can be used as set screws to hold your barrel attachment in place.

A registered charity run by volunteer scientists on 4 continents Help us design good, affordable lab equipment for African scientists!

Also, check out our dedicated lab.equipment tinkering page: http://open-labware.net ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// Currently I have made this for iPhone 4 and 5 (sub-types fit as well), but it should be a one-minute job to fit it to any other phone using the customizer - explanations in the attached pdf. For lenses, I use these (http://www.aixiz.com/store/product_info.php/cPath/46/products_id/374/osCsid/37cabc139b4f03b0e0a522178defae7e) which are 10 lenses for 10 US$, but any odd lens should do. You'll also need an M3 boat and an M3 screw of about 20 mm. I hope it is all pretty self-explanatory. Note1: If you do modify this for another phone type (and have tested that it actually fits!), could I ask you that you please either upload it as well, or drop me a note so I can add it here. It would be nice to have versions for all kinds of phones. Thanks! Note2: for iPhone, I can recommend the app "Camera+" which I think is free - it allows you to do a few key things, such as keeping the flash permanently on, or to disable autofocus (which can be annoying)

description.text: This is the second rendition of my Raptik phone case, I've made a lot of changes to reduce plastic and size while keeping the phonecase durable. There are now two slides instead of latches for ports, as well as plastic toggles to replace the difficult to press rubber bumpers. This also means that the entire case can be printed without flexible filament if you want. Although I still recommend you use a soft filament for both left and right bumpers. Tolerances for this case are tight! It is recommended you print at 1-2% bigger to account for plastic shrinking! you will need 8 3M 10mm screws for this, or if you would like a flush fit, 15mm screws ground down to size. I have included the duel extrusion files I used for my case as well as the standard versions. This version is still experimental and I will likely be making adjustments to it as I go along, feedback welcome!

author: billpealer

title: X-Axis Motor Mount, Strengthened
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The standard equipment on the Tevo Tarantula leaves quite a bit to be desired. I noticed that the stock x-axis motor mount was flexing when I would tension the belt, so I decided to create a more sturdy mount for that motor. I have seen a couple of versions of this here on Thingiverse, but my design is more solid and, in all probability, like most of my designs, over-engineered.

To install this, you will need the following hardware:

8x m4 x 10mm screws (4 of which come with the standard mount)
8x m4 T-slot nuts (4 of which come with the standard mount)
4x m3 x 35mm screws
7x 4mm washers (you cannot fit a washer on one of the eight m4 screws)
4x m3 washers
2x 5mm nylon spacers (one of which is used on the standard mount)

Installation should be obvious from the CAD drawing and is similar to the standard mount with the exception of the front plate. All four m3 screws go through both halves of the mount into the stepper motor. The idler pulley is sandwiched between the two halves of the mount with a 5mm nylon spacer on either side of the pulley. The m4 screws go through the plates so that the t-slot nuts are on the inside, with washers between the screw and the plates.

There are two "top" plates here. Version 1 is the strongest, but I found that it interfered with the mounting of the oldham coupler and the z-axis drive rod, so I modified that to version 2. You may want to print the v2 top plate if you think your rod is going to get in the way :)

I went through four designs when modeling the top plate, so in the photos of this installed, I have not yet replaced the (intermediary) v2 plate with the (final) v2 - I simply removed the two outer mounting screws, so... go by the CAD drawing and not the actual photographs.

In the photo I've uploaded of my test tower, you can the vast improvements with each modification I've made. From left to right, the first tower is prior to my latest upgrades. The second tower is after installing the no-sanding oldham coupler (not my design). The third tower is after installing this upgraded motor mount.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

80%

Depending on your printer tolerances / settings, you may have to drill the holes out a bit for a loose-ish fit. Drill the m3 holes (the ones used to mount the stepper motor) with a 1/8" drill bit. Drill the m4 holes (the ones used to secure the mount to the rail) with an 11/64" bit. You may also have to run a small rounded file through the holes through which the rollers go for a snug, yet not too tight, fit.

description.text:
Was browsing and searching for a mount bracket that I could use to mount the 2.5W blue laser to my wan hao to do some laser cutting of double sided tape for car badges (longer story). I came across a different design but down in the comments he gave a link to all the original files (which included the i3's metal extruder main x-carriage bracket). It was from OnCAD, so once I figured out how to export it to something Fusion 360 could understand, I began to further the guys design into a laser mount. All the other guys bodies should be there, just disabled, it was an extruder mount of some kind.
I designed the laser module and mount, have included the .f3d files as well as the .step/.stl's for the whole project in case you want to remix it for your needs. It's designed to use the parts fan wires to fire the LASER on/off. It uses 3/16" Rare Earth Magnets (from Radioshack), but also has the i3's two screw holes in case you cant get a hold of similar magnets for faster mounting.
To use this you will need to unscrew the hot end assembly from the main x-carriage bracket with the two M3's that attach the hot end to the bracket, same screws could be used to mount the LASER bracket.
To mount the LASER to this bracket you should use 12 mm M3 screws (flat head). But other M3 screws would also work. Threads shouldn't exceed much beyond 13 mm from face of bracket into LASER body. I'll update if I can find what links I used to get to the i3 main bracket to speed up my development time, thanks Mr Guy for the share of your wanhao i3 bracket.

title: Asus Crosshair Hero VI X370 plates

description.text:
I have an Asus Crosshair Hero VI X370 motherboard-based AMD Ryzen system installed in a Thermaltake Core W200 case. Because of the design of the case (can accommodate two complete computers in one case) cable routing is difficult. Hiding the cables for one side of the case displays them on the other side. So I purchased 4 sheets of ABS plastic in a size of 24"x24"x1/8" to cover up the cables.

You cannot completely hide all cables since they still need to be connected to the motherboard but you can hide most of them behind the abs sheet. Cutting access holes in the abs sheet with simple hand tools is doable but the results can look, well, not so great. (see picture without the red plates)

I designed the plates to be mounted to the ABS Sheets to cover up any mistakes made while cutting the access holes to the cables (See second pic with the red plates)

Use some 1/4" screws to mount the printed parts to the sheet and then install the sheet.

title: False Panel Spacers and Retention Screws

description.text: I have two computers installed in one case. The case is the Thermaltake Core W200. As you may expect, when there are two computers in one case, cable management suffers because hiding cables from one side displays them on the other. So...the only way I found to get a cleaner install was to purchase sheets of ABS panels in 24"x24"x1/8" and cut them to fit the case. In order to create a false bottom where I could hide the cables I needed spacers to create that void. These spacers are 24mm tall. They are mounted to the motherboard tray on either side. The ABS panel (after it's been cut to fit properly) is then placed in the case up against the spacer and the screw hole is marked and drilled into the ABS Plastic. Then use the included screws hold the ABS panel in place. (Not shown...currently drilling holes so I can use the screws)

title: University of Wisconsin Badgers Logo Wine Stopper

description.text:
This is a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:92162 which is a University of Wisconsin Logo. Here I added a base to the logo with a hole in the center. A wine stopper can be threaded into the hole. The wine stoppers I had were metric and I didn't have any metric taps, so I just turned the wine stopper thread into the hole and it was able to cut its own thread in ABS. The original suggested printing two, in different colors, and attaching them. I wish I had made the logo twice as thick so it would be more robust. I'm not worried about it breaking during normal use, but it feels a little more fragile than I'd like. Overall I'm happy with it and didn't want to spend more time on it as this is a one-time gift for a friend.

I was honestly hoping to find a model of Bucky to attach to the wine stoppers, but I couldn't find one online and that type of 3D modeling isn't my forte.

Notes:

To achieve the two-tone effect I waited until the base was finished, cut the black filament, and fed in red filament to the printer. This could also be achieved by pausing the print and changing colors. I didn't test a single color version, but I suspect this coloring really makes the logo stand out. If anyone prints it in all red I'd love to see it. ABS was used and worked well for the self-tapping method. Untested with PLA.

Hole Adjustment

The hole here was spec'd at 5mm and I printed another at 6.8mm for two different wine stoppers with different threading. (I think I had a 3-outer-layer part thickness with a light infill.) I had to use a drill to shave off a little of the inside of the hole in order to get the thread of the wine stopper to bite. I held the 3d print in a vise and twisted the wine stopper in by hand, drilling out a little bit more if it wouldn't go. The chamfer on the hole could possibly be bigger; as drawn it might not have had any effect. From a test piece, it seems the wine stopper can be unscrewed and rescrewed without loss of stability.

description.text:
I am in the process of installing a Keenovo silicon heat bed to my Creality CR-10S and decided to go this route for using a Solid State Relay to pulse AC power to it instead of overloading the existing 600W DC power supply.

I wanted to create a quick standalone case for the parts that I bought for this build. There is nothing complex with the box, and the dimensions are 100mm x 100mm x 200mm. This will accommodate these parts listed below:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0087ZTN08/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: Laser cut MDF Star Wars Legion launch pad

description.text:
Inspired by the Battle Kiwi kickstarter pieces for Star Wars Legion, I decided to dust off the old k40 laser cutter and CAD'd up these terrain pieces. They're cut out of 3mm baltic birch, but MDF is the preferred terrain wood. This is my first laser cut terrain piece and it's sort of my 'learning' bit so it's not too terribly detailed. I designed it to be either a missile silo or an escape launch pad. The detail pieces are engraved, the rest are laser cut.

I am sharing out my svg, I used it to design the order of laser operations per path. I've also included the sketchup file I used to export the shapes as an SVG to laserweb4.

Any Legion terrain makers, want to collaborate?

description.text:
The logo and text are cutouts on the back of the case and do not show through. The case had a weak spot when I did this at the tip of the logo. Flip over the case in thing view to see them.

The case itself is from creator Teece and the logo is from Nehuen93.

I didn't change the actual dimensions or anything about the case itself, just added the logo and text. For the logo I had to play around to get the cutout just right since the back part of the original logo was a little wonky. I used Tinkercad to do all editing and add the text.

The case is extremely snug, which I am a big fan of. For mine I used a transparent PLA but I'm sure a flexible/semiflex or ABS would work well too.

This is the first thing I've ever put up. It's not spectacular but I really wanted an Assassin's Creed case for the iPhone X and so I decided to see if I could make one.

UPDATE 2/21/2018
So when printed the original file the logo was extremely thin and warped pretty bad because of it. The one labeled as modified has it being a little bit thicker as to hopefully solve this but I have not had a chance to print it yet. I printed the first one with the back of the case on the print bed but depending on what you'd prefer, you could probably print it with supports and the back of the case facing up.

title: 530:1 Planetary Reduction Gearbox for NEMA 14 Stepper Motor

description.text:
I needed a 200:1 reduction gearbox for a project and couldn't find one online, so I decided to try and design one. The end result was printed on a Creality CR10 at 0.06mm layer height in PLA. Much to my surprise, it actually works as designed. The final assembly is just 6mm longer than a standard NEMA 17x38mm stepper motor.

The design is in modular stages, each of 4.8:1 and so can be customised for different gear ratios. For my application I used 3 stages and a .9 degree stepper motor. This gives 110:1 with 0.008 degrees per step. Print in Nylon or PETG for a usable component

Saved as three STLs for a three-colour print.
Merged as one object to produce the mono-colour STL version.

description.text:
The Old Cathedral of Lleida (in Catalonia) was build between 1023 and 1431. Started in Romanesque style and ended in Gothic. In 1707 ,the infamous king of Spain Philip the fifth, ordered to destroy the cathedral but the order was never executed.
The tower is 60m high and the cloister is one of the largest in Europe.
The 3D files contain only the tower and cloister, that is about half the monument.
Check Wikipedia for more details at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Cathedral_of_Lleida

The Gothic windows were taken from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:815120

UPDATE Feb 26: Uploaded V3 files. The tower windows have been changed (more windows but simplified) and the tower body has been separated from the cloister. The .Simplify 3D factory file has been included in case you want to modify it.
The GCODE for V3 was generated for 1.7mm PLA, 0.4 nozzle, 215C, Base 60C, speed 50mm/s and medium quaity.
When printing, use the same scale for the tower and cloister. "46pc" means that were generated at 46 percent of the original design size, resulting in a 90mm height tower and a 97mm by side cloister.

I used the same phone to record both videos about two weeks apart. It is so dramatic that when I was editing the video to upload just now I noticed the sound amplitude bar on the after video was almost flat so I uploaded a screenshot of it.
I set the printer up in a bonus room upstairs on an Ikea HEMNES
Coffee table and while we couldn't hear the fan noise downstairs we could hear the stepper motors as the vibrations resonated loudly in the hollow floor and drywall between the first and second floors. The first step was to install NEMA dampeners https://smile.amazon.com/dp/B073FRZTDX on the X and Y axis stepper motors. The second was to print and install racquetball feet. That got rid of all the vibrations but I still didn't like how the CR-10's control box sounded like a 747 getting ready for takeoff so I replaced all the control box fans and that did quieten it down some but not much so I printed and installed Midevil1's excellent dual 120mm fan base and used two Noctua NF-S12A 120mm fans https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00BEZZBFO and that was the pièce de résistance! The S12's are quieter and move more air than the P12 or F12 versions making them ideally suited as a case fan. You would use the P12 or F12 for cooling a radiator since they have higher pressure but they are louder. I also ordered a Noctua NA-FC1 PWM fan controller so I could turn the fan speed down a bit if needed but it turned out it was completely unnecessary as the fans were whisper quiet at max speed so I removed the controller and direct wired the fans so there was one less thing that could go wrong. The only thing is I didn't need the wire grooves or exit holes on the fan base since I was powering the fans from the internal power supply so I filled them in and removed the CR-10 logos. I kept the control board fan as it is not very loud but I did remove the rear exhaust fan since I aimed my fans down to pull air from the bottom of the case. My reasoning is that there are vents at the top so I figured it would be better to pull in fresh air from there and have it blow across the main control board and then with the way the power supply is positioned most of the air is drawn down into it from the rear and blows across all the power supply components before exiting. Of course it will work fine blowing in but I think I remember reading somewhere that pulling air from a computer case produces better cooling than blowing air in. Oh and the other thing I did to quieten it down is to replace the hot end fan with a Noctua 40x10 https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B009NQLT0M

We started off by looking for an affordable pan-tilt mechanism to make a cat laser game. We found this nice model on Thingiverse by Fernando Bueno from 3D Open Hardware and it was a great starting point. The mechanism has 3 parts. We remodeled the top part of the servo and added a small dome with a hole so that the laser diode could fit in it. The other 2 parts we printed as is.

The build details will be posted on our blog soon!
In the meanwhile, you can see the project on our Youtube channel >> https://youtu.be/XzmFdUfj8iU
The wiring instructions are here >> http://bit.ly/cat-laser-circuit
And the code is on our github repo >> https://github.com/Circuito-io/LaserCat

Home 3d printers tend to be inaccurate, so if the laser doesn’t fit into the hole, you can use a 6mm drill manually to make it a bit bigger. Just make sure that you don’t drill all the way because the end of the hole is a bit more narrow and prevents the laser from popping out of its place.

This is an ab roller I came up with but forgot to share here. I'm using a dowel in the center for grip. You'll need a 200 mm x 200 mm bed plate as this will take up most of it. You could scale it down, but you'll have to find an accompanying dowel for a handle. The inside diameter of the hole is 30 mm. So, if you scale by 0.8 (80%) you'll need a 0.8 * 30 mm dowel or 24 mm.

I designed it to use a 0.8 mm nozzle for expedient print times. I printed mine in PETG with 3 outer layers (0.8*3) and a 20% infill. I think that this might have been a bit of overkill, but it's better not to fall apart while using it. I also took into consideration that not everyone has carpeted floors, so the channel in the center of the outside is meant for rubber bands if need be. The amount of plastic laid down was, of course, another consideration.

This winter was quite shameful for me. The 'dirty bulk' was all dirty, no bulk. Time to change that. Being rather tall, extra weight is detrimental to my knees. Remember, weight loss is all about caloric (energy) burn vs. caloric intake. If you're taking in 3000 kCal but you're only burning 2000 kCal, you're going to store that extra 1000 kCal as fat. The opposite will happen if you're burning more than you're taking in. If you're burning more, you will lose weight. Weight loss is not that hard folks, it's a matter of will power and energy burned.

Make sure to get your protein everyday and drink plenty of water. Adult males need 56g, adult females will need 46g, 75g if pregnant. The human body can gain a maximum of 2 lbs a month in muscle mass.

I'm linking a video that illustrates how to use an ab roller effectively and correctly.

https://youtu.be/MpsPFQF0FOU

Of course, I'm not a doctor and results may vary. Consult a medical professional if you're concerned about your health.

title: Round push key for indoor privacy lock

description.text:
A simple one-handed push key for interior doors with round privacy locks. We got tired of looking around for a skinny screwdriver or lollipop stick whenever we happened to lock ourselves out of our bedroom, so I threw this together in Blender. Simply insert the long end into the hole and push in the base from your thumb in order to open a door that uses this style of privacy lock. I've included a picture of our own doorknob for reference.

The base is 27mm in diameter and 4mm thick while the rod is 4.35mm in diameter and 33mm long. This was designed specifically to fit perfectly in our doorknob, so the dimensions may or may not work for your own locks. As such, you can download the original Blender file and adjust the dimensions to your liking.

UPDATE 2/21/18: Uploaded a modified version with a chamfer for added stability. My test prints have done just fine without one, but now the option is there if you're worried about it breaking.

I really liked the shape of lolmodule's YETI handle and thought it would be easy to remix it to fit the small Ozark Trail 10 oz. tumbler from Wal-Mart but it turned out to be quite the challenge. Most slide-on tumbler handles are designed with a very gradual taper that naturally squeeze a tall tumbler as they are pushed upwards. I tried that with this one but the angle was much greater since it such a short tumbler so I could never get it tight enough plus it comes to a bulge near the top before tapering back inward again toward the lip. I finally figured it out in OpenSCAD by using two opposing cones stacked on top of each other so they hug the bulge. I rounded the edges of the cones using Robo's Rounded Primitives. Print it upside down at 100% infill with no supports and simply push it up from the bottom of the tumbler until it won't go any farther and it will almost snap into place. I scaled the handle down way smaller than I thought I would because I found you really want to hold this small tumbler more like a coffee cup with three fingers than the full-fisted grip of a monster tumbler. Anyway, TMI, hope you like it :)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lnAuxQwQQVM (Red)

description.text:
We installed a sliding door in our kitchen and needed a handle, so I designed and printed one!  
The handle has a curved design, with a recessed back. You need to drill/chisel a hole in your door and fit the handle into the hole. This way your handle does not get in the way if you needed to slide your door fully open.  
I'm new to 3D printing and design so, as always, my designs are a work in progress and can be edited if desired.

I printed this design on a Replicator 2. When I uploaded the file into maker ware it was positioned so that the front surface of the design is on the top. You need to make sure you add supports, which can be removed from the back once the design has printed. With the supports on the back it means any rough surface should be hidden when you mount it onto the door. It was printed at
Infill: 30%
Shells: 5
Layer Height: 0.3mm Once printed, measure the recess section and draw this onto the position on your door. Using a drill with a wood piece attachment, drill small holes around the shape you have drawn on the surface. My door was hollow on the inside so the shape then just popped out, but you may need to chisel out the hole in the wood. REMEMBER DON'T GO THROUGH THE ENTIRE WIDTH OF THE DOOR - you should NOT be able to see the handle on the other side of the door. I screwed the handle in place using 32mm plaster board/dry wall screws.

title: Universal Scraper with replaceable "blade"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed an all-plastic scraper for removing parts from my printbed, and for scraping/brushing plastic bits away after printing without risking damaging the bed surface, and found Andycap's "universal scraper". After a short while mine got too dull to use, then had an unfortunate meeting with some acetone, so I decided to remix it, separating-out the scraping edge of the tool and turning it into a replaceable "blade" piece similar to a typical utility blade.

This way, I won't need to re-print the whole tool when the edge gets too dull to use.

The blade is to be secured with two roughly 3.5 x 6 mm screws, with threads appropriate for biting into plastic. 9/64" or M3.5 machine screws will probably work too, as will SAE #6-32's. A pair of M3's might work in a pinch, depending on how well your printer is calibrated. The back edge of the blade fits under a lip, which takes up most of the force from scraping, so the screws only need to be snug enough to hold the blade in, they need not be in super-tight. Note that this does NOT accept actual metal utility blades.

I also took the time to try to clean up the faceting a little (just to make it easier to edit), and I've rotated the models to the right orientation for printing.

Being that the blade is kinda thin, you probably don't want to use this remix to go scraping ice from your windshield. :-) It's intended for light-duty uses where a metal blade is not acceptable.

description.text:
I wanted a knurled thread protector for my airsoft g n, so I took aubenc's Knurled surface finishing library and enone's Airsoft M4 Threaded Flash Hiders and mashed the models together! This ends up being a bit wider than a standard metal knurled thread protector, but it works the same.

Note: Threading is 14MM COUNTER-CLOCKWISE. Meaning you screw it "tight" to the left and "loose" to the right. Airsoft g ns and real g ns are generally threaded this way. To print this as a right hand "clockwise" thread, you just need to mirror the model - as such, I've included the master Blender file.

This is a housing for the RAMPS graphical controller which can be mounted onto a makerbeam frame or other place where you can bolt it on to a surface or supporting rails with m3 bolts.

Print one of the housing, positioned face-down and with support turned on.

Print one of the button cap, top face down, with no supports.

Make sure the button doesn't bind in the hole once printed.

Mount the controller using the holes in the 4 corners of the LCD PCB behind the panel, using 4x 8mm M3 hex stand offs, 4x M3 nuts and 4x M3*6mm bolts.

This is a remix from dionlevi's capsule holder.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:745377
It was already really nice, but I thought it was a shame that the rotation is just using plastic over plastic friction.
So, I decided to give my first try at blender to modify it so you can fit a 608RS bearing between both parts.
F608ZZ will work too, and you won't have to worry about pushing the bearing too far in the hole.

Included are both short (172mm height) and tall (200mm height) holders.

Step 1, print both parts (0.2mm, 20% fill density, 1.2mm shell, top and bottom were used on my CR10, printed in PETG)
Step 2, fit the bearing inside the hole in the holder. no glue needed, if you need a bit of sanding, keep it minimal in this area or you will need some glue.
Step 3, put the holder on its base and fill it.
Step 4, enjoy your newly made capsule holder, what else?

I also included some test files so you can check how well your bearing will fit without printing the whole parts.

Small video of it spinning:
https://youtu.be/dKVSu7Q8J-U

author: celebrity208

title: Leica Mz6 microscope - phone camera adapter

description.text:
Stereo microscopes are common in electronics etc labs, and would be convenient to be able to capture photographs of what one sees. Our Leica MZ6 does have another viewport for attaching a camera, but that would apparently require an expensive adapter and an SLR with a suitable lens, rather expensive for our random needs. Cheap USB microscopes can be used for that, but accurate focusing with them is much harder.

This adapter allows most phone cameras be used with a Leica MZ6 microscope (probably others, at least by some cutting, also mono microscopes), by just placing the adapter on one of the eyepieces and placing the phone on it so that the view is visible on phone screen. No additional focusing needed, just focus by eyes and throw in the phone.

This adapter also has slots for an additional phone specific adapter, if required, haven't bothered yet.

BTW: the phone needs to be placed rather accurately for the picture be captured, at first some experimenting needed.

Overview

A stereo microscope is convenient for any kind of working with ~millimeter scale objects, this adapter allows using a common mobile phone to photograph objects through such a microscope.
Investigate small things, photograph with own phone.

• A microscope with eyepiece like that of a Leica MZ6
  • PLA/ABS/whatever print material
  • A cell phone with a camera
  • Tiny objects to investigate and photograph

As mechanical designer, I use in intensive way a 3D Space Navigator device (model 3DX-700028 Standard Edition), for 3D modeling in Computer Aided Design applications.
Thus I decided to design this simple hand-rest, to increase the work comfort, saving at the same time a little bit of money.
I dimensioned the 3D model, with proper measures and coupling tolerances, in order to be easily assembled with the 3D Space Navigator device.
The hand-rest is essentially made up of two elements, the main part has been made by a generic 3D printer, using material PLA black coloured.
As contact surface whit the hand, I used a flat and soft piece of sponge, having a properly rounded shape, sticking it into the pocket located in the rear side of the hand-rest by means of strips of bi-adhesive tape.
Then I inserted carefully the 3d Space Navigator device inside its rounded housing, including the interfacing USB cable to the PC, which will be placed into the suitable slot located in the front side of the hand-rest.

description.text:
Used a spatula to remove print parts but wanted something sharper and more compatible with hammers. This one has a slot for a utility knife blade, which is tilted so that the blade edge perfectly meets the print plate when lightly pushed from above. Also easily removes skirts etc 1st layer traces and glue from the print plate.

Use:

  1. Push a utility knife blade into the slot. Use glue, if blade too loose, my current one is fine without glue.
  2. Place the tool on the print plate, blade just touching the part to be removed.
  3. Lightly hit the tool end with a hammer.
  4. If the part didn't snap off, continue tapping with the hammer until it does.

description.text:
This is a belt tensioner I developed to assist in tracking down vibration problems on my printer. It has a knurled knob for reproducible adjustment.

The parts should be easily available but as supplied it is designed specifically for an OpenBuilds/Ooznest 'smooth idler pulley' (22mm diameter, 16.2mm high) and to fit on 2020 v-slot extrusion configured for pulling an OB gantry plate on wheels.

You are welcome to tweak the scad file for your needs! The key variables you will want to change are partsOnly and beltOffset. If you need to change the idler dimensions much smaller the belt will rub against the mount, so you will need to do a bit of work to make appropriate space. Also note the 'reg2020flip' boolean to control which side the hole for mounting to the extrusion goes on -- or just remove this cube and create your own mount.

Hopefully you find the code sufficiently well documented, if not clear -- apologies in advance otherwise :-)

Also some parts definitely need support to print. The STL files supplied have been processed with MeshMixer to include the supports, that's what I use.

You can easily overtighten to stretch and deform your belt with this, and after it runs out of stretch the mechanism will transfer vibration artifacts to your prints. Don't do that.

idler wheel - STL files are sized for OpenBuilds 'smooth idler pulley'
m5 bolt, 25-30mm
2x m5 nuts
spring - like for print bed (came with my cheap i3 clone, bought many off ebay, m5 bolt fits inside)

A simple solenoid mount I have designed to hold a small solenoid in place for a theater production.  I needed to create a remote system to drop a small chandelier.  I came up with the idea of using a solenoid connected to an X10 remote.  
The design holds the solenoid box in place, and is just long enough to prevent the pin from falling out.  The solenoid I used to design this thing is a "DC 12V 2A Pull Type Linear Solenoid Electromagnet 10mm 20N".  This fourth version should have all the dimensions right.  I have been using Inventor Fusion, that does not have very easy measuring tools, thus the need for the revisions.

I measured the solenoid with the pin in it to get the maximum internal dimension of the overall design.  From there, I added a couple of holding bits that fit the solenoid box, without impeding the pin and spring.  I designed the 2D cutout in Photoshop CC and extruded it to 3D.

title: Anti-backlash T-Nut X-end for Prusa i3 MK2/S

description.text:
This is a modified X-end parts for the Original Prusa i3 MK2/S. MK2S SCAD files were used as the source. The modification was made to the X-end to hold an anti-backlash T-nut with

  • M3 hole at 16mm diameter
  • 22mm flange

You may need other parts of the OpenSCAD files if you're planning to modify the scad files. The original scad files can be found at Prusa Research website.

2018/03/03 Update: I uploaded the wrong STL for the idler side, it has been corrected. Thanks @Rhinhardt for pointing it out.

Prusa

i3 MK2S

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I guess it's better to print with PETG or ABS, but I've printed with PLA and so far had no problem with it. The X-axis motor doesn't get so hot that it deforms the part.

Assembly

Please note that the spring on the nut may be squashed more than it should(~5mm more), you may need to cut some of it if you don't want it to be that tight.

It was a matter of understanding the SCAD syntax. The include file got me confused for a bit when I tried to find the line to tweak. OpenSCAD doesn't have a way to let you find the part you want to modify quickly, but I guess it's just like reading any open source code. This printer mod was a great learning for me on OpenSCAD.

title: ESP8266 2.9" e-paper MyMonitor Enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fonctionnement :

Toutes les 10 minutes, l'esp8266 se réveille, prend des données à partir d'un site Web, affiche les résultats sur l'écran e-papier et se coupe. L'écran e-paper permet de conserver l'affichage des résultats sans consommer de courant.

Voici la liste des composants utilisés :

1 x esp8266
1 x ecran e-paper 2.9' waveshare
1 x chargeur TP4056 Lithium
1 x Lipo battery 3.7v 240mah

Le schéma de câblage de l’écran est le suivant :

BUSY -> GPIO4
RST -> GPIO2
DC -> GPIO0
CS -> GPIO15
CLK -> GPIO14
DIN -> GPIO13
GND -> GND
3.3V -> 3.3V

Pour la bibliothèque logicielle, j'ai utilisé celle-ci :
(https://github.com/ZinggJM/GxEPD)

Documentation sur la bibliothèque :
(https://forum.arduino.cc/index.php?topic=487007.msg3323227#msg3323227)

Operation :

Every 10 minutes, the esp8266 wakes up, takes data from a website, displays the results on the e-paper screen and turns off. The e-paper screen keeps the display of the results without consuming power for that.

Here is the list of components used:

1 x esp8266
1 x ecran e-paper 2.9' waveshare
1 x chargeur TP4056 Lithium
1 x Lipo battery 3.7v 240mah

Pinout for the screen is :

BUSY -> GPIO4
RST -> GPIO2
DC -> GPIO0
CS -> GPIO15
CLK -> GPIO14
DIN -> GPIO13
GND -> GND
3.3V -> 3.3V

For arduino library, I used this :
(https://github.com/ZinggJM/GxEPD)

Informations about library :
(https://forum.arduino.cc/index.php?topic=487007.msg3323227#msg3323227)

title: Vacuum adapter for filament storage in ziploc bags

description.text:
This is a vacuum adapter to remove the air from a ziploc bag to vacuum seal filament. Removing as much air as possible allows the desiccant to do a better job of reducing the moisture content in the filament and the surrounding bag. This adapter is for a Black & Decker Flex portable vacuum but should fit other vacuums with a 30mm hose size. This is especially useful for nylon and other flexible filaments which absorb moisture very quickly.

After removing as much air as possible I put a rubber band around the bag and filament to help keep the bag from taking on more air.

https://youtu.be/5dA8YRc2Rs0

comments.text: Sadly I have found that the plastic in ziploc bags is gas permeable, so not a permanent solution.  YMMV of course, where I live 80-90% humidity is not uncommon...
comments.author: robmlr

comments.text: Yes, you need to also use desiccant packets.  Preferably the ones that change color as they become saturated.  Put them where they are visible. Hopefully they will keep up with the permeation of the bags and not require changing too often. I also put a mini digital hygrometer in the bags of flexible filament.

title: Filament roller guide for Anet A8

description.text:
I hung all my filament on the side of the cabinet that my printer is on (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2775181) so I needed a low resistance guide to steer my filament up and over the top of my printer and back down to the extruder. I quickly drew this up and it's not pretty but it works GREAT. It uses two 608zz bearings, one to swivel and the other as a roller for the filament. I used a 16mm long piece of m8 threaded rod to hold the bearing and screw the two halfs of the roller together.

You'll need two m3 screws that are ~4mm longer than the stock screws.

If I were to redesign this I'd:

  1. Make the base plate smaller and move the bearing closer to between the two screws
  2. Redesign the fan/fence on the guide's roller tower
  3. increase the clearance between the two sides of the roller tower**

** I'd do this because I designed it so that you can just force thread the m8 rod into the holes on the roller tower halves but when I did this I didn't thread them in perpendicularly AND the threads that I did "cut" in weren't "clocked" correctly so when I'd screw it down and align the two halves the roller bearing would bind. I was able to re-"tap" the threads on one side and with a little sanding it's working great now. Still though, assembly was a P.I.T.A.

UPDATE: I modified the base plate (new file is v0.4) to be smaller (12mm less wide) so that it takes less time & filament to print.

description.text:
This is a turret only for use on the 28mm (1/56th) scale Warlord/Ilateri KV1 tank kit. This will be of interest for fans of the Bolt Action gaming system. The standard KV, at "regular", will cost 350 points. The KV1S (a version used in the mid war period) was lightened to allow more speed (hence the "S" in the name); in the game this model loses the "armour all round" of 10+, but also looses the "slow" rule, and cost a whopping 70 fewer points - 280 points for a regular tank with 10+ frontal armour, a medium AT gun with 2" HE, and three MMGs.
In this model I started with Bergman file and upscaled the turret, re-did the main gun barrel to be more robust, added a turret pivot to fit the Warlord model. The fit is nicely snug. It will not fall out if held upside down, but slides on without issue. It could just be my print settings, results may vary.
I have done up two versions; one with the rear turret MMG to be printed and a second with a void in place of the rear MMG, in case someone wished to use an alternate method of representing the MMG.
As always, please be careful when removing the print supports.

title: Rounding Hill for Elementary School Students

description.text: This is a tool to help students achieve a concrete understanding on how to round numbers.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Finder

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Default

Infill:

Default

Notes:

I used a raft to help with the curling issues that I had been having.
CCSS

Overview

Students will learn how to round a number.

Lesson Plan

Teacher will show students how to round a number, such as 12 on chart paper. Students will copy the anchor chart in their Student Journals.

Step 1:
Teacher will show students to find their number and underline it. If rounding to the tens place, that would be the 1.

Step 2:
Teacher will show students to "look next door" to the right, which will show the underlined number what to either round up or round down. The number in the example is 2.

Step 3:
Teacher will show students that if the number on the right is 4 or less to "let it rest" and keep the underlined number the same.

Step 4:
Teacher will show students that if the number is 5 or greater, to add 1 more to the underlined number.

Step 5:
Teacher will make sure students understand that all numbers after the underlined number will become a Zero, and that numbers before the underline will not change.

Students will take a look at the "Rounding Hill", which will show the concrete example of rounding. Students will imagine a toy car stopping on the numbers. If the car stops on or before the 4, the toy car will be pulled by gravity back down to the 0, and will let the underlined number rest. If the toy car stops on or after the 5, gravity will pull the car down to the right side, signifying that they will add 1 more to the underlined number.

Anchor Chart

Materials Needed

Student Journals, Pencils, Chart Paper, Markers, Rounding Manipulatives.

• Rounding
  • Number Sense
  • Math
15-30 Minutes

Preparation

Gather materials, print out several Rounding Manipulatives.

title: Adapter for M39x0.75mm Enlarger Lens on Sony E Body

description.text:
This is a simple focusing adapter that I made for my Rodenstock Omegaron 150mm f/4.5 enlarger lens to be used with my Sony E-mount cameras. This particular enlarger lens has a 39mm diameter thread with 0.75mm pitch -- beware that many enlarger lenses have different threads (including 39mm with 1mm pitch). The tube length is intended to work with lenses from about 135mm to 180mm with a good focusing range, although focusing is slow because the focus thread has just a 3mm pitch.

The Sony E mount on this part is designed for the later all-metal E-mounts, and it is a loose fit on most E-mount bodies -- I might revise this, but it is usable as is. The last three photos were taken using this lens and focusing adapter on a Sony A7. Note that there is very slight vignetting, which is due to the width of the opening in the adapter; it is not yet clear if the vignetting can be avoided by using a wider tube design.

MakerGear M2

20-25%

Notes:

The inner part was printed in black PLA. The outer part was printed in translucent bronze PLA -- which looks very pretty, but is NOT light tight. Don't use a translucent PLA unless you intend to take other steps to make the material light tight. Both are easy prints, but be careful if your printer tends to knock-over tall narrow parts; a little brim might help prevent that.

To make the bronze outer part light tight, I painted the inside with Black 2.0. Although any black paint might suffice, Semple's Black 2.0 is exceptionally matte and black, and it covered in one coat; the only disadvantages are that it easily scratches off and it is much more expensive than the flat black latex wall paint I used to use for this purpose.

Also make sure your enlarger lens doesn't have fiber optic channels for backlighting the aperture display using light from the enlarger. (This one doesn't, but many do.) Those channels can work in reverse to cause fogging when the lens is used for taking photos. A dab of black paint or tape over each fiber optic port will prevent the fogging.

Firmware Marlin 1.1.8 adapté pour la DiscoEasy200 de base avec option écran, à flasher avec Dagom'App.

Fonctionnalités :

  • BabyStepping (ajustement du Z offset en temps réel lors de l'impression de la première couche, double-clic lors de l'impression pour y accéder)
  • Nivelage du plateau en 9 points (au lieu de 4)
  • Affichage du numéro de la couche en cours
  • Affichage du pourcentage d'avancement de l'impression
  • Affichage du temps restant approximatif (plus précis sur de longues impressions, la valeur peut être faussée en début d'impression si vous n'avez pas fait préchauffer votre buse).

(Utiliser les branchement d'origine de Dagoma pour les capteurs de fin de courses.)
(Le temps restant est calculé en fonction du temps écoulé et du pourcentage d'avancement)

Je n'ai pas rencontré de bug lors de l'utilisation de ce firmware, mais je vous conseille de rester non-loin de votre machine si vous décider de l'utiliser au cas où.

Néanmoins, merci de me signaler tout bug ou bizarrerie si vous en trouvez afin que je puisse les corriger.

author: sebballl

title: E3D clone DC42 IR sensor and 40mm radial part cooler adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Designed for a HE3D K280 delta printer; would doubtless work on K200 and many other Chinese deltas that use a E3D clone hotend having a square cold-sink block with 4x unused mounting holes on the reverse side to the fan (17mm apart). It leaves the grub-screws securing the heatbreak accessible.

A version without the fans is provided as a DC42 IR mount if you already have part cooling.. And a version without the IR42 mount to complete the set..

The DC42 IR board is protected from the heatblock by a backing plate, with allowance for the through-plated pins of the connector and capacitor. Some vertical adjustment is allowed for on the main mounting bracket so it can be lowered when using volcano hotends etc. On my rig I have the assembly pushed up as far as it goes, which clamps the LED light ring in place, and leaves the IR level offset at approx 1mm.

Fan version uses 40mm radial fans, NOT the 50mm ones that came with the K280!

  • Be Warned! it makes your effector wider than normal, make sure you still have clearance to belts and towers on your maximum travel (it is tight on my K280, but nothing touches)
  • 40mm blowers are quiet and small enough to fit under the effector carriage configured for a 'big mouth' effect, blowing down on the whole print, but angled in on the nozzle.
  • I may return to this and separate the fan mounts into something that prints separately, and flat, which would allow me to add some simple ducting to make the air go more towards the nozzle for PLA work. Maybe even make a 50mm fan version.

Use a silicone sock on the hotend to ensure it does not get cooled too much by the fans as they come on, and to protect the IR probe.

Not the prettiest thing once printed due to small size and some nasty overhanging angles; even printing slow and small-layered it needed a bit of cleaning up (craft knife.. take care) and the fan holes reaming out.

SCAD file included; dont laugh.. it's ugly. My first attempt OK!

title: DIY Trigger Style Electric Skateboard Remote
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was searching for a suitable remote control for my DIY electric skateboard but I found nothing that was suitable for my needs. Trigger style remote + telemetry readout.

After building and hacking several together, I ended up with this design of my own based on electronics and software from solidgeek (https://github.com/SolidGeek/nRF24-Esk8-Remote/tree/development).

The remote I designed has the following features:

  1. A dead man's switch which deactivates the throttle when the remote is not held (safety feature because the trigger can accidentally go off otherwise, ask me how I know)
  2. A mode switch which swaps between displayed data (Speed, distance, battery voltage, Ah drawn, current draw)
  3. Ergonomic OLED display position so you don't need to twist your wrist to read it.
  4. Menu to adjust settings
  5. Programmable deck selection via menu
  6. Calibration of throttle via menu
  7. Ambidextrous design, swap to left hand use by adjusting the script
  8. Skate bearing used in trigger mechanism for smoother operation as well just a fun detail considering it's meant for an esk8
  9. Hall sensor instead of potentiometer to prevent potential wear of a pot

Youtube video available at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gQl7mLMAiAs&feature=youtu.be
Part List available at https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1vXR9ce0m25Ap6XxzlymFo_pfpIeT2RAqWCypW-a-Jes/edit?usp=sharing
PCB Files available at https://easyeda.com/ervinelin/New_Project-35f7bf3537744cda8e1064904f6a78a5
Firmware available at https://github.com/ModMiniMan/nRF24-Esk8-Remote
Build guide available at https://github.com/ModMiniMan/nRF24-Esk8-Remote/wiki
Forum discussion available at https://www.electric-skateboard.builders/t/diy-trigger-style-remote-with-telemetry-complete-guide/48231

You will need to have intermediate soldering skills to complete the build as well as knowledge on how to program an Arduino and adjust simple code. Of course if you print this yourself you will need to know how to 3D print.

Caveats:
Remote is experimental and not an off the shelf product that has undergone proper testing. Build and use at your own risk. Please bench test extensively before actual use. Lastly, I highly recommend protective gear when using the remote just in case something doesn't work (many many things can go wrong)

Squobe

She is a beast!

Link to flight in action.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=swnC-unI4x4

I used http://ardupilot.org as a guide for setting up and configuring her.
I included pics of the wiring from the under carriage- the batteries are wired in series with an adapter, then into XT60 that leads to the BEC which branches out to the flight controller.

The other end of the XT60 then goes into a jerry rigged 4 barrel plug breakout that leads to the ESCs- 2 in the front, 2 in the back.

The ESCs and the power for the LEDs run through the holes in the bottom of the body and under each arm. Might need a bit of thermoforming to make passage for ESCs leaving undercarriage.
They then connect to the motors with barrel connectors. And power to the LEDs with JST connectors.
If you crash and break an arm- the connectors will disconnect and won't damage your components.

There are also little power breakouts directly from the barrels that go into the batteries- they lead to BECs in the front undercarriage that power an OSD and the LED systems in each arm.

I zip tied some pool noodles to the under carriage for when you're coming in hot!
Best $2 I ever spent. I put 6 inches of wooden dowel in the center of the pool noodle to add some form.

Check the Ardupilot literature for thorough guides to setting it up- because I don't remember!

Parts list below- total cost is about 600-700 with spare batteries and props.

You'll need a variety of lengths of 6-32 bolts and square nuts for screwing the frame together.
https://www.amazon.com/Hard-Find-Fastener-014973314453-6-32-Inch/dp/B00L1L72OY/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1519142469&sr=8-2&keywords=6-32+nut+square

And you'll need some longer screws to attach the motors. And BTW- Hobbyking no longer stocks the motors I used but something equivalent will do fine.

description.text: A seej cannon I designed to launch pennies in volleys of either one, two, three or stacks. It didn't work as well as I hoped for a stack of pennies but works wonders in launching nerf darts. Features include trigger, variable power (easily attach additional rubber bands for mroe power) and angle adjustment.

The hammer rods fit in the hammer and the trigger cap. The hammer rod in the hammer is pulled by one end of the rubber bands and then other end of the rubber bands is held on by the pegs on the main cannon. The trigger also grabs onto the hammer rods to hold the hammer in place. The trigger cap is placed at the back of the main cannon to hold the trigger and prevent the hammer from falling out when no rubber bands are attached. Enjoy and be safe. 2-4 rubber bands should be sufficient in launching pennies a considerable distance and do not aim at eyes. Never look down the barrel if rubber bands are in place.

author: mussy

description.text:
This mold is used to create uniform 52mm x 52mm ravioli. For anyone who has tried making ravioli without such a tool they're aware that it's time consuming to make a product that is visually appealing.   
Commercial molds are often the size of a cupcake pan which is great for making many pieces at a time but takes up too much space for my liking. As such, I designed both a single as well as four piece mold.   
I use the single and it worked out great last week. Next time I use it i'll make sure to take pictures.

• Lightly Flour the inside of the mold.

  • Cut rolled pasta dough into squares just larger than the mold.

  • Press dough square into the mold so that it sits smoothly against the surface.

  • Drop filling into the depression (personally I like a mix of ricotta cheese, mashed potatoes & spices for a really quick easy fill)

  • Use a wet brush (or your fingertip) to lightly dampen the remaining dough showing.

  • lay another pasta square over to seal your raviolo. Lay the middle down first and press from the middle out to push as much air as possible out as you seal your dough.

  • Firmly press along the edges of the mold, using the raised edge to cut off excess dough.

  • Flip mold over to release your beautifully crafted and fresh Pasta!

  • Drop in boiling water. Depending on the thickness of your pasta dough (which for ravioli is usually rather thin) fresh dough will cook in just couple minutes. The rule of thumb is that when your pieces float, they're done.

  • Plate well and give to your spouse, watch them swoon.

title: Slim LED Holder for Qidi Tech 1/FFCP

description.text:
This is a remix of FlashForge Nozzle Light V2 by frasersnow.

I use an Arducam, which sticks pretty far into the printer, so I couldn't use frasersnow's front back plane, so I used the rear back plane. But even that didn't work well for me, because it hung too low in front of the camera and obscured the view of the nozzle. So I imported the rear back plane into Tinkercad and reduced the height to 11mm. I also replaced the wiring holes with 1.5mm holes that nicely line up with the electrical contacts on the LED strip.

I'm too lazy to tear my printer apart to get to the power supply, so I used an external 12v power supply for the LEDs. You may want to tap into your printer's power instead.

No additional hardware necessary.

title: Spare tire bike rack for mountain bike

description.text: This is my spare tire bike rack. It bolts to the spare tire mount using the spare tire lug studs, and is sandwiched between the mount and the spare. It is based off of a Yakima Sparetime carrier. The rack is tilted to avoid a top tube adapter. The bike is secured using two quick fist clamps.

I based it off of a Yakima Sparetime, but I didn't want to have to use a top tube adapter, nor did I want the bulk of a tire tray. I designed it around my Specialized Stumpjumper Comp, which has a top tube angle of about 15 degrees. I cut the steel with a CNC plasma and a metal bandsaw, but a cutoff wheel would do. I welded a 1/2-13 nut into the bracket, into which a knob with stud (McMaster 60965K362, $12.50) screws. I drilled some holes in the knob, and made a short stainless cable to lock the knob from turning. This prevents someone from walking away with the bike and rack together, as well as any inadvertent unscrewing of the knob on the road. I also welded on some tie down rings at the top and bottom for bungees prior to powdercoating. There is a 1/16" metal plate in the larger center square tube on the rack to make up for the rack OD/bracket ID. I zapped a 1/2" washer onto the end of the 1.25" tube for the knob to pass through. I designed the bracket around my spare, which is 255/75/17, so if your spare is thinner, you may want to make the bracket tube shorter. As it is, it comes out to about flush with the sidewall. The bike is secured using two quick fist clamps. A bungee minimizes wobble, and a cable lock keeps it secure.

After welding and cleanup, the whole business was powdercoated using a Harbor Freight powdercoating setup, and black wrinkle from Powder buy the Pound (https://www.powderbuythepound.com/s-s-black-wrinkle.html).

Bracket BOM

1x 7x0.125" round plate
1x 3x1x1" square tube (may shorten)
1x 1x1x0.125" plate with 0.53" hole centered
1x 1/2-13 nut

Rack BOM

2 to 4x 1x1x0.125" plate (for covering ends of square tube)
2x 15 3/8x1x1" square tubes
2x ~6x1x1" square tubes
2x 6x1" round tubes
1x 2 1/2x1 1/4x1 1/4" square tube
1x 1x2x0.0625" plate
2x standard quickfists (Amazon, ~$11)
1x 1/2-13 knob with stud (McMaster 60965K362, $12.50)
1x 1/2" steel washer

remixed_from.title: ZeroBot - Raspberry Pi Zero FPV Robot

description.text:
More info: https://hackaday.io/project/25092-zerobot-raspberry-pi-zero-fpv-robot/log/97988-the-new-zerobot-pro
Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oSEvLNrP1fQ
Raspberry SD card Image: https://drive.google.com/file/d/163jyooQXnsuQmMcEBInR_YCLP5lNt7ZE/view?usp=sharing

The ZeroBot Pro is an updated version of the ZeroBot from last year. It includes many new features such as a charging port, more battery capacity, battery voltage sensing, headlights, camera mode, safe shutdown and a new UI.

Notes:

Print the two shells with the inside facing the print bed. You will need to include a lot of support material. Simplify3D works best for this, but Slic3r or Cura with optimized settings should be fine as well. I used support with lower density for the most part and higher density for the last 8 layer up to the part. This saves a lot of filament.
The tires should be printed with Ninjaflex or something equivalent to ensure good grip.
Everything else can be printed in PLA.

Create smoothly curved containers such as bowls, urns, or vases with this customizable design. Beginning with a side view, you draw Bezier curve control points in a polygon widget; the resulting curve is turned into a cross section that is spun as if on a lathe or potter's wheel to produce the final model. Here is a brief screencast demonstrating how to draw Bezier curve control points with this customizer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hVwQY6czCPw The attached screenshot overlays a frame from the screencast with additional details.
Produces solid models intended to be printed with zero infill and zero top layers. (Alternatively, stop your printer around 90% to prevent top layers from being printed.)
Part of my Customizable Containers series.

remixed_from.author: AK_Eric
remixed_from.title: X-CARVE Dust Shoe (NewBrit Design) - big hole

description.text:
DISCLAIMER ALERT Don't use this STL file, I simply had to include one to upload this. DO NOT 3d print this, if you want to 3d print, use AK_Eric's files which are linked below. I'm not responsible for any broken bits, misscut pieces, etc, use and cut at your own risk.

I took AK_Eric's dust shoe from his complete design and made it out of acrylic so I could see the working surface better. Firstly, I'd like to thank AK_Eric for designing the file, I simply modified it so it could be cut on my x-carve out of acrylic. Instructions are divided into Fusion 360 users and Easel users. This is designed to be used by 58mm (~2.25") vacuum tube with the Dewalt spindle.

Fusion 360 Users:
Obviously use the .f3d file and upload to your F360. The file should have the CAM settings already programmed for you. Flat tipped 1/8" single flute up cut bit is what this is programmed for. I have mine set to use 1/4" (6.15mm) cast acrylic. I used speed setting 5 on my dewalt router to cut this. You will have tabs on all of the through cuts to prevent ejection, just break the piece out and file to finish. Tabs are 1mm high to allow for inconsistencies in material height. I didn't add a facing pass because I didn't care enough to add one. Now that you have the model you can modify to your hearts desire, I am not a fusion 360 expert, so if you don't think the settings are right, go ahead and change them :). You will need the rest of AK_Eric's files to finish this which is linked below.

Easel Users:
Download the gcode file (.nc extension). This is setup for you to simply import into easel and get to cutting. To do so open a new Easel project, click import, select gcode, upload the file from wherever you saved it, and the preview will load. You will have 25mm of space on the x-axis and y-axis to place clamps. I suggest using a 1ft x 1ft 1/4" (6.15mm) thick piece of CAST acrylic. You must use 1/4" (6.15mm) cast acrylic for this to cut properly. Cutting time is ~24 minutes, so be prepared to stand at the machine with a vacuum to cut this. Once your file is uploaded, click carve and proceed through setting up the machine to carve like you normally would. After the cut is done you will pop the piece out of the acrylic and file the tabs to finish. Use a hot glue gun to glue in your bristles of choice. Download and print or have printed the rest of AK_Eric's files per his instructions to be able to install your new dust boot.

Once again, I'd like to thank AK_Eric for making this awesome file. I simply modified it to make it perfect for cutting. This is for the xcarve dewalt spindle and a 58mm (2.25") vacuum tube. Download the rest of the files here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2173106

remixed_from.author: slonold
remixed_from.title: Nimble Gimbal - Gimbaling Extruder Motor Mount for Zesty Nimble

description.text:
I saw slonold's Nimble Gimbal and liked the Idea. slonold did a great job on his design. I needed to modify it for my application.

  1. I needed to make the arms wider at the bottom so it would mount on a 2020 aluminum
    extrusion beam.
  2. I want to use M4 bolts to attach the arms to the 2020 beam so I increased the M3 holes
    to M4. (A little over kill)
  3. I have a dozen 624 bearings and wanted to utilize them. I increased the size of the
    bearing housing to accommodate the 13mm x 5mm bearing size of the 624's.
  4. Also used four bearings instead of the two in the original design. (A little over kill)

Needed supplies:
Print one set of arms and one extruder_mount_bracket.
6 M4 x 16mm bolts, 4 for the arms to bolt to the 2020 beam and 2 for the bearings.
4 M4 x 20mm bolts for mounting the Zesty Extruder Motor mount to the gimbal bracket.
18 M4 flat washers (8 for the 4 bolts to mount the Zesty Motor mount to the gimbal bracket
(optional), 4 for the M4 bolts that mount the arms to the 2020 beam (optional) and 6 for
the M4 bolts that make up the two bearing assemblies).
6 M4 nylon lock nuts, 4 for the Zesty motor mount to gimbal bracket and 2 for the arms to
gimbal bracket.
4 M4 'T' nuts for the M4 bolts the attach the arms to the 2020 beam.
4 624 size bearings.
Assembly Instructions:
Assemble the bearings first by using 1 M4 x 16mm bolt, 3 M4 washers and 1 nylon lock nut. Slide 1 M4 washer onto the bolt followed by a 624 bearing, then another M4 washer followed by a 2nd 624 bearing. Then slide the third M4 washer and lastly the nylon lock nut. Now tighten the bearing assembly. Make one more assembly.
Take 1 bearing assembly and insert it into the bearing housing on the motor bracket button head first. Do the same for the other bearing assembly.
Please see the provided photos for assembly.

title: HF Braun LED work light stability base

description.text:
The Braun LED work light is fantastic from harbor freight, but unless you have a metal surface, the light does not like to stand up.

I went through several iterations to get the tolerances just right, but every printer is different. You want to get the fit snug, but not too snug where you need a hammer to get it back off. So if it doesn't fit perfectly the first time, scale it up or down by 0.5 percent and work from there.

title: Spacer for SRX Magnetic encoder am-3445 FRC robotics

description.text:
This is a spacer that allows the SRX Magnetic encoder (am-3445)
to be properly spaced above the Toughbox Mini (am-2236) or similar. The magnetic encoder is manufactured by CTR Electroncis and also sold by Andymark.com and is used in robotic building such as for FRC First Robotics competitions.

As of late 2017 / early 2018, the Toughbox gearbox included shaft now has a magnet in the end,
the benefit is that you don't have to machine a magnet into the end, but the drawback is that
the old way of mounting the magnetic encoder now requires an additional spacer such as
SRX Magnetic Encoder Mounting Hardware Kit (am-3565), but that kit is simply a grommet.
This 3d printable part is a spacer that should be of proper (approximate) height to go green with the LED.

Height of this part when printed in PLA should be 8.8mm. You can scale in Z if you need more / less height,
or you can sand some material off, or perhaps shim with milk jug material. We used 12mm long 3-48 type screws.

You can try 1/2" screws or cut a custom length screw. Note you only want about 3 mm of thread to enter the Toughbox Mini's black plastic, as below that plastic is a bearing, try not to go into area of bearing.

Other thoughts are that if you did print this with Flexible material, then you could adust height by screw tension (again dont enter area of bearing by going too deep into Toughbox).

And notes about proximity of magnet to encoder.
red and orange led if dist from magnet to detent of underside of encoder housing is 2.95mm or greater.
green led if distance 0.75mm to 1.5mm

title: Geeetech Z axis lead screw adapter

description.text:
I bought two Nema17 steppers with integrated TR8x8 lead screws (the price has gone up a lot since I bought them, so shop around for a good price) to replace the stock threaded rod, but they were about 20 mm to short to reach all the way up to the bracket.
The solution was a new extended top bracket with a 608 bearing.
Stl:s for the left and right brackets and the Sketchup design file included.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20% (not critical)

Notes:

I printed with three layer perimeters which turned out fine.

No supports to remove.
Drill out the hole for the linear guide with an 8 mm drill.
Press the bearing in with a vise.
When you change from an 8 mm, 1.25 mm pitch threaded rod to TR8x8 lead screw you have to recompile the Marlin firmware.
In configuration.h, change
#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT { 78.74, 78.74, 2560, 105 }
to
#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT { 78.74, 78.74, 400, 105 }
to reflect the higher pitch and lead.
You might also want to increase max feed rate from the default 2 mm/s to something higher.
In this case, I set it to 6 mm/s.
#define DEFAULT_MAX_FEEDRATE { 400, 400, 6, 45 }

This puts a higher load on the steppers as the gear ratio is higher, so you might have to increase the max current on the driver(s). Check the instructions for your drivers, but it's usually just a matter of turning the small potentiometer til you get a somewhat higher voltage reading.
The Z axis drivers operate only for fractions of a second per printed layer, so there's no big risk in dialing in a fairly high current setting.
Depending on your printer setup, you might have to reduce maximum print height. Install adapters and move the Z carriage up to see your max height.
Set #define Z_MAX_POS 180 to your whatever is your new value.
